Python has some pretty good string libraries. Since you are generating python code, would it make more sense to do it in python? It also avoid the extra jvm dependency, which makes it much harder to use for windows/centos users etc

There are close to 5 issues which have been opened by different users for a similar problem and in every thread I see that the contributor closes the issue because of "lack of activity". I don't know why are you not solving the issue in the first place. ? Sorry for being rude but this is the harsh reality.
@cjolivier01

Hi @SrivastavaKshitij. I checked the above five listed issues and they all come from different usage (i.e. different code), so I think it's premature to claim them to be the "same problem". Thus, I don't think an issue that aggregates them would be logical or helpful. If you have evidence to support such claim, please do share. Otherwise, if you have specific error that you need help with, please follow the issue template and provide necessary information. Thank you for your cooperation.

@SrivastavaKshitij I apologize if the auto-message upsets you. The "lack of activity" in the automatic message merely refers to this issue being inactive in terms of not having new comments, nor an issue-label that's being tracked.

On this specific issue, this (i.e. shape mismatch) is the most common user error in symbolic programming, which is part of the reason why contributors are less inclined to help. So please do realize that asking for help on this issue is in most cases equivalent of asking others to debug your program. If you believe this is due to a bug in the code, please consider providing a minimum reproducible sample code, in which the API is used as intended but the result isn't. Thank you for your cooperation.

> Some files don't seem to have any license. E.g. batchnorm.st.

These files are string templates. If I place license in these files, the license will go into the generated code. 

> Some sort of guidance/document on how the translator internally works will be useful since from what I see there are bunch of components for this translator. Such details will help 1. reviewers better do the review and 2. for anyone else who wants to fix any issues with the translator later on when you are not around.

> Do you think having better class docs would be helpful for anyone trying to maintain the code?


Totally agree. These are on my list but haven't had the time to do it. Will get to it after the first release. 

> No unit tests?

Unit tests unfortunately is tricky to write. For example, to test the convolution layer generator, I could do some string processing on the output to validate it but that will be too fragile (will break when output changes a little). Ideally, test code should use MXNet to load the generated symbol and verify it but loading incomplete networks (like just one layer) might not be possible. Testing the generated code using a parser is a chicken-egg problem. 

That said, I do have tests at macro level - tests that will translate a full caffe network, run training using the generated code and test for convergence. Those tests are available [here](https://github.com/indhub/caffe_translator_tests). I haven't created a PR for those yet because I need to figure out some licensing related issues. The test code translates some Caffe example code taken from Caffe repo and tests for convergence. I need to figure out what I need to do to use caffe example code for testing without infringing on the license. Planning to merge these tests after the first release. 

> Do you think it'll be good to exit in case of exceptions like this or this? Basically fail fast in case of issues? Or would it make more sense to generate a code-comment which says "// Couldn't convert lr policy" and continue. Also, with that in mind, what do you think about having a force flag to the translator which if present ignores such errors and continues instead of exiting?

In the first case, it will be nice to print a error message saying the caffe prototxt is not well formated. The translator currently assumes the Caffe code is well formatted and it is runnable using Caffe. 

In the second case, it will be nice to add a comment to the generated code indicating the problem. 

You are right.  Adding a comment in the generated code or printing to the console and proceeding with the translation is more preferable than aborting. This is because, as a user, the generated code is helpful to me even if certain parts is not translated. I can manually add few lines to complete the translation. 

These changes are now done. 

> Probably integrate FAQ with the main README since main README doesn't have too much info? (this may just be my personal preference though).

I'll move the list of supported layers to README. Will leave the question about why caffe in the FAQ page. I don't think that is important enough for the README page. I do get your point about there being less content in faq. But more might get added by the time this work is complete.

> Out of curiosity what happens when this returns null?

If there is no data layer in the Caffe prototxt (maybe because the prototxt uses ImageData), this could return null. In that case, the generated code will not have a data iterator. Supporting more data layers like ImageData is in the roadmap but not for the first release.

> Generally good to have braces for if statements even if it contains only one statement. Also spaces b/w if and () would be good everywhere. See google braces guide and whitespace guide for more. I'm assuming fixing now would require too much effort w/o giving enough in return so feel free to choose accordingly.

Fixed.

> I'm seeing some inconsistencies regarding use of final modifier. E.g. here and here. Generally good to be strict unless we there is a reason to not be.

Fixed.

> (Minor) Instead of calling this GenHelper GeneratorHelper may be a more appropriate name since it clearly says what is it about.

Fixed.

> Also it would be good to expand the imports such as this.

Fixed.

Installing JVM on CentOS:
```
sudo yum install java-1.7.0-openjdk
```

For windows, it is pretty much point click and install:
```
https://www.java.com/en/download/help/windows_manual_download.xml
```

I’m not sure it is easier to write the translator is Python because the target language is Python. 

That said, I don’t strongly lean one way or other in the choice between Java/Python. I preferred ANTLR/StringTemplates/Java simply because there was a lot of documentation and sample code and it was easy to get started. We could certainly spend some time writing a prototype in Python and evaluate if it makes sense to move to Python. That won’t be a quick work to do for the first release though. We can do it in a subsequent release.

Also, if you're new to mxnet, we have a new high-level interface called "Gluon" that's a lot easier to use and faster to develop than the previous symbolic interface. We have a set of awesome tutorials to showcase its usage that you can checkout at http://gluon.mxnet.io/

One possible reason is that an input argument for the executor you are creating does not exist in the shared executor's argument set. The arguments in the executor you are creating and shared executor must have the same name for reusing memory.

You can first consider the ndarray that `take` is operating on as a matrix (2D). If it's more than 2D, flatten it into 2D by keeping the first dim and collapsing all the rest dims into the second dim. For a 2D ndarray (matrix), `take` op simply extracts the rows specified by the index array and stack them one by one to form an output ndarray.

In your case, let's say `eq_flag` shape is (4,), then the output of the `take` has shape (4, 1024, 48, 64).

It's a bug in the sampling op. The following code would crash at commit 3226bce2c912bd0289be171c7025a6651e025407:
```python
 import mxnet as mx
 from mxnet import nd
 ctx = mx.cpu(0)
 x4 = nd.uniform(low=0, high=255, shape=(2, 1024, 14, 14), ctx=ctx)
 print(x4.shape)
```

It would help if some dmlc people got on general@ and dispute these issues rather than just Apache committers try to make a case for dmlc people's wishes and restrictions.

We should solve this by not including any 3rdparty source code in the release tar.
For example we can't add asf header to nvdia cub

In my opinion the behavior should be consistent between the different cases

mx.nd.zeros(10, mx.cpu())  -> shape=(10,)
mx.nd.zeros(10, mx.cpu(), stype='csr') -> error
mx.nd.zeros((1,10), mx.cpu(), stype='csr') -> shape(1,10)

so that a sparse vector or a dense vector can be used in the same code without any particular adaptation.
It also requires some other changes around in the code (#8883)

Solved! @reminisce This is because I write this code in my symbol:
```
p3 = mx.sym.broadcast_mul(x,y)
```
and every time this code was called,this will give an unique operator name for this operator. When bucket key changes the symbol changes.
Thank you!

If you're interested I have dockerfile to build amalgamation for android [here](https://github.com/edmBernard/DockerFiles)
```bash
git clone https://github.com/edmBernard/DockerFiles.git
cd DockerFiles
make mxnet_android
```
I will try to build amalgamation with your Dockerfile as in mine I use clang instead of gcc

The root cause seems to be the incompatible MKLML-library defined in the MKLML-Dockerfiles:
```
RUN wget --no-check-certificate -O /tmp/mklml.tgz https://github.com/01org/mkl-dnn/releases/download/v0.10/mklml_lnx_2018.0.20170908.tgz
RUN tar -zxvf /tmp/mklml.tgz && cp -rf mklml_*/* /usr/local/ && rm -rf mklml_*
```
This MKLML-version only seems to be compatible to Ubuntu 14.04. 

Updating the library with the following causes the test to pass - make sure to update MKLML to v0.11 if you're running ubuntu 16.04:
```
RUN wget --no-check-certificate -O /tmp/mklml.tgz https://github.com/01org/mkl-dnn/releases/download/v0.11/mklml_lnx_2018.0.1.20171007.tgz
RUN tar -zxvf /tmp/mklml.tgz && cp -rf mklml_*/* /usr/local/ && rm -rf mklml_*
```
not sure about icc, have you seen this? https://software.intel.com/en-us/forums/intel-c-compiler/topic/338378  otherwise you might have to use a different stl
We also use clang for android, won't compile without clang due to stl.
commit

The new shape should not change the array size when you use array.reshape under recording scope of autograd or reshape operator, this line should be `CHECK_EQ` https://github.com/apache/incubator-mxnet/blob/master/src/ndarray/ndarray.cc#L84. But the size can change if not under recording scope, https://github.com/apache/incubator-mxnet/blob/master/src/ndarray/ndarray.cc#L73.

`dot` is `matrix dot operator`. The shape should be (m, n) of lhs and (n, k) of rhs. I think this check `inputs[1].shape().ndim() == 2 (1 vs. 2)` makes sense.

You can replace `b=nd.zeros(10,)` with `b=nd.zeros((10, 1))`
So last pull request not merged will show here too.

```
>>> a=nd.zeros(10)
>>> b=nd.zeros(10)
>>> nd.dot(a,b)

[ 0.]
<NDArray 1 @cpu(0)>

>>> a.shape

```

Uhm, that tutorial is on random numbers and that Iterator is used on a numeric MLP example

`mx.nd.reshape(a, shape=(3,3))` used operator `reshape` which requires the output and input have the same size, while ` mx.nd.arange(12).reshape((3,3))` called backend `NDArray` class member function which only requires the output size is no greater than the input size. This is a legacy naming issue. Should solve it for eliminating confusion.

@ZiyueHuang Anyway, the dot operation causes the python VM to crash.

```
class PReLU(gluon.HybridBlock):
    def __init__(self, *args):
        super(PReLU, self).__init__(*args)
        with self.name_scope():
            self.alpha = self.params.get('alpha', shape=(1,), init=mx.init.Zero())
            self.act = gluon.nn.Activation(activation='relu')

    def hybrid_forward(self, F, x, alpha):
        pos = self.act(x)
        neg = F.negative(alpha) * self.act(F.negative(x))
        return pos + neg
```

This is how hybrid block works
FYI sparse support is available in python: https://mxnet.incubator.apache.org/versions/master/api/python/ndarray/sparse.html

Regardless of `self.alpha.data()`, that still doesn't work with hybridizing. Even calling `prelu.hybridize()` before `prelu.initialize()` causes the same problem (errors below). Are there any plans in the future to release a 'prelu' standard activation function; something like `gluon.nn.Activation('prelu')` in the future?

    In [22]: out = prelu(test)

    Stack trace returned 10 entries:
